actual_capabilities: Guide skill creation process from understanding use cases to validation
Explain progressive disclosure design (metadata ‚Üí SKILL.md ‚Üí bundled resources)
Define proper skill structure with scripts/, references/, examples/ directories
Provide writing style requirements (imperative form, third-person descriptions)
Demonstrate trigger phrase design for skill auto-discovery

use_cases.title: Validate Skill Quality

use_cases.title: Learn Skill Architecture Patterns

output_examples.input: I want to create a skill for managing database migrations in our Django project.
output_examples.output: Guides user through: (1) Understanding concrete examples of migration tasks, (2) Planning reusable resources like scripts/migrate.py and references/schema.md, (3) Creating skill structure in plugin-name/skills/database-migrations/, (4) Writing SKILL.md with trigger phrases like "run migration", "create migration", "rollback database", (5) Organizing detailed SQL patterns in references/, (6) Validating the skill structure.

output_examples.input: My SKILL.md is 4,500 words. How do I make it follow progressive disclosure?
output_examples.output: Analyzes current SKILL.md, identifies sections that are detailed reference material vs core workflow instructions, recommends moving detailed patterns to references/patterns.md and advanced techniques to references/advanced.md, keeps only essential 1,500-2,000 word overview in SKILL.md with clear pointers to reference files.

best_practices: Use third-person in frontmatter description: "This skill should be used when..."
Include specific trigger phrases users would actually say
Write in imperative/infinitive form, not second person
Move detailed content to references/ for progressive disclosure
Provide working examples in examples/ directory
Create utility scripts in scripts/ for repeated operations
Reference all supporting files clearly in SKILL.md
Study plugin-dev's skills as templates (hook-development, agent-development, etc.)
Test skill triggers on expected user queries
anti_patterns: Vague descriptions like "Provides guidance for working with X"
Everything in one 5,000+ word SKILL.md file
Using second person ("You should...", "You need to...")
No specific trigger phrases in description
Duplicating information across SKILL.md and references/
Creating directories (scripts/, references/) without actually needing them

faq.question: What's the difference between references/ and examples/?
faq.answer: references/ contains documentation meant to be read by Claude (schemas, patterns, detailed guides). examples/ contains working code files that users can copy and adapt directly (runnable scripts, config files, templates).

faq.question: When should I create a script vs just document the approach?
faq.answer: Create a script when: (1) the same code is repeatedly rewritten, (2) deterministic reliability is critical, or (3) the operation is complex enough that having executable code is more helpful than instructions.

faq.question: How do I know if my skill description will trigger correctly?
faq.answer: Include exact phrases users would say: "create a hook", "validate settings", "run migration". Test by asking Claude those questions and verifying the skill loads. Vague descriptions like "helps with hooks" won't trigger reliably.

faq.question: What's progressive disclosure and why does it matter?
faq.answer: Progressive disclosure is a three-level loading system: (1) metadata always in context, (2) SKILL.md loaded when skill triggers, (3) references/scripts loaded as needed. This keeps context efficient‚ÄîClaude only loads what's necessary for the current task.

faq.question: Can I use the init_skill.py script for plugin skills?
faq.answer: No. The init_skill.py script is for generic standalone skills. Plugin skills are created manually in the plugin's skills/ directory with a simpler structure focused on the needs of Claude Code plugins.
